whereWouldINeedThisFormTip.title: Ship Tip: When would I need this form?
whereWouldINeedThisFormTip.text:
Depending on the commodity and country or territory of destination, certain exports from the United States may require a U.S. Certificate of Origin.

See country or territory specific regulations and restrictions

applyNAFTADutiesLever.label: Would you like to apply for NAFTA preferred duties for this item?
applyNAFTADutiesLever.name: hmc_apply_nafta_duties

naftaCertofOriginTip.title: Ship Tip: When should I use a NAFTA Certificate of Origin
naftaCertofOriginTip.text: Goods shipped between the countries or territories of Canada, Mexico, and The United States are often eligible for reduced or waived duties under the terms of the North American Free Trade Agreement. In most cases, products must be at least partially made or assembled within these countries or territories to qualify. For commodities valued above a certain amount (per country or territory), a NAFTA Certificate of Origin is required for preferential tariff treatment.

hmcDifferentKindOfProductLever.helper_txt: For example, a t-shirt or baked goods would not be sold the same as the cotton or flour they are made from.

costofMaterialsTip.title: Ship Tip: How do I figure out the cost of materials in a product?
costofMaterialsTip.text: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amit, consectetur adipiscing elit.

validIDsTip.title: Ship Tip: What type of IDs are valid for this form?
validIDsTip.text:
Depending on the nature of your shipment, several ID types can be used:

  • For individuals, a Social Security number (SSN) will suffice.
  • Business shippers can use either an Employer identification number (EIN) or the D-U-N-S(c) Number (DUNS) for their address. An EIN is a tax ID issued to a business by the IRS; DUNS is a widely recognized location-specific identifier from Duns & Bradstreet.
  • A foreign entity may use a valid ID form issued and recognized by their government or region, such as a VAT ID. If no other number is available, a passport number may be used for an idividual exporter.

hmcInternalShipLever.label: Is this an internal shipment by parties in the same organization?
hmcInternalShipLever.name: hmcInternalShipQuestion
hmcInternalShipLever.help_btn: A related party transaction means that either the sender or receiver owns at least 10% of the voting securites of the other party. This would exclude any shipment involving individuals not representing a business, or a business shipping to a customer.

hmcBondedGoodsLever.label: Are you shipping bonded goods?
hmcBondedGoodsLever.name: hmcBondedGoodsQuestion
hmcBondedGoodsLever.help_btn: Goods shipped in bond are unloaded directly to a bonded warehouse where they may be stored for up to five years. Bonded goods are considered "in customs' custody" during this time, and are not processed for import duties until checked out by an agent of the sender or receiver.
hmcBondedGoodsLever.helper_txt: Also known as an inbond shipment

hmcShipFTZLever.label: Will you ship from a foreign trade zone (FTZ)?
hmcShipFTZLever.name: hmcShipFTZQuestion
hmcShipFTZLever.help_btn: A foreign trade zone or FTZ (also called a free trade zone) is a regulated area where import goods can be stored and processed without customs duty. An FTZ is similar to a bonded warehouse, but with less restrictions to use.

hmcDangerousGoodsLever2.label: Does this shipment contain dangerous goods?
hmcDangerousGoodsLever2.name: hmcDangerousGoodsQuestion
hmcDangerousGoodsLever2.help_btn: Dangerous goods (corrosive, flammable, explosive, toxic, or otherwise hazardous materials) are subject to strict guidelines for shipping. Dangerous goods may only be shipped internationally on a contract basis. See ups.com/hazmat for regulations and licensing information.

hmcRequireExportLicenseExemptionLever.label: Does this product require an export license or exemption?
hmcRequireExportLicenseExemptionLever.name: hmcRequireExportLicenseExemptionQuestion

exportLicenseTip.title: Ship Tip: How do I know if I need an export license?
exportLicenseTip.text:
Only about 5% of exports require an export license. If your shipment involves government or military agencies, certain countries or territories or end users, or if a product has a 'dual-use' military or weapons-engineering function, you may need a license or an exception code to export your product. more...

The Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) divides licensed products into 10 categories:

0 - Nuclear materials equipment and miscellaneous components

1 - Materials realted to chemicals, microorganisms, and toxins

2 - Materials processing

3 - Electronics

4 - Computers

5 - Telecomuunications and information security

6 - Sensors and lasers

7 - Navigation and avionics

8 - Marine equipment and accessories

9 - Propulsion systems, space

Each regulated product has a 5-digit export control classification number (ECCN). If you're exporting a retail item manufactured by another company, chances are they've already classified the item. Look for the ECCNs on the company's website, or find your product on the Commerce Control List: www.bis.doc.gov

Even if your product is listed, it doesn't always mean you need an export license. Every ECCN has one or more 'reasons for control,' which do not apply equally to all countries or territories. Find your country or territory of export in the Commerce County Chart to see if any 'reasons for control' apply: Commerce Country Chart

If you need an export license:

Apply online with BIS through the SNAP-R portal. There's no fee for filing. Be aware, though, that it can take up to six weeks to get a license processed and approved, depending on volume.

You can search for denied parties, detect export licenses, and search import and export regulations by country or territory with our TradeAbility international tools: TradeAbility

hmcfileAnEEILever.label: Do you need to file an EEI for this item?
hmcfileAnEEILever.name: hmcfileAnEEILever

whenAmIRequiredToFileAnEEITip.title: Ship Tip: When am I required to file an EEI?
whenAmIRequiredToFileAnEEITip.text:
U.S. Customs requires an Electronic Export Information (EEI) filing when the value of an item (or a quantity of that item) in a shipment exceeds US$2,500.00. Certain items require an export license for shipping in any quantity or value.

You may file your EEI directly with U.S. Customs, or we can file on your behalf for a fee.

hmcITNLever.label: Do you have an Internal Transaction Number (ITN)?
hmcITNLever.name: hmcHaveITN
hmcITNLever.helper_txt: This number confirms your EEI when you self-file with U.S. Customs.

hmcITN5Lever.helper_txt: This number contains your EEI when you self-file with U.S. Customs.

hmcITN7Lever.name: hmcHaveITN7
hmcITN7Lever.helper_txt: This number confirms your EEI when you self-file with U.S. Customs.

Only about 5% of exports require an export license. If your shipment involes government or military agencies, certain countries or territories or end users, or if a product has a 'dual-use' military or weapons-engineering function, you may need an license or an exception code to export your product. more...

The Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) divides licensed products into 10 categories:

0 - Nuclear materials equipment and miscellaneous components

1 - Materials realted to chemicals, microorganisms, and toxins

6 - Sensors and lasers

7 - Navigation and avionics

8 - Marine equipment and accessories

9 - Propulsion systems, space

Each regulated product has a 5-digit export control classification number (ECCN). If you're exporting a retail item manufactured by another company, chances are they've already classified the item. Look for the ECCNs on the company's website, or go to www.bis.doc.gov to find your product on the list.

Even if your product is listed, it doesn't always mean you need an export license. Every ECCN has one or more 'Reasons for control,' which do not apply equally to all countries or territories. Find your country or territory of export in the Commerce Country or Territory Chart to see if any 'reasons for control' apply.

If you need an export license

Apply online with BIS through the SNAP-R portal. There's no fee for filing. Be aware, though, that it can take up to six weeks to get a license processed and approved, depending on volume.
